content.description: Retroviruses such as <math alttext="H I V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HIV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and hepatitis <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> virus use <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> as their genetic material rather than <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. In addition, they contain molecules of reverse transcriptase, an enzyme that uses an <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> template to synthesize complementary <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
content.question: Which of the following best predicts what will happen when a normal cell is exposed to a retrovirus?

choices.label: The reverse transcriptase will cut the host <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into fragments, destroying the host cell.

The reverse transcriptase will insert the viral <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into the host’s genome so it can be transcribed and translated.

The reverse transcriptase will produce <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from the viral <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which can be incorporated into the host’s genome and then transcribed and translated.

The reverse transcriptase will force the host ribosomes to translate the viral <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> prior to polypeptide assembly.

content.answer: The reverse transcriptase will produce <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from the viral <math alttext="R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which can be incorporated into the host’s genome and then transcribed and translated.
